location.physicalLocation: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

mods.abstract: Two rows of African American men wearing formal attire and fez hats with "Keblah" on them. The first row contains 8 men, either seated or kneeling on one knee; the second row has 8 standing men in the same attire, with 2 additional men wearing business suits and hatless on either end. The setting for this photograph is an interior space, with a draped window niche at back. A label with handwritten indentification " Dr. C.S. Boyd Illustrious Potentate Keblah Temple #78" has been placed over the image.

titleInfo.title: Keblah Temple #78, African American Photography Collection, MS.2129, University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Libraries

mods.accessCondition: Reproduction permitted for non-profit educational and research purposes only. All reproductions require acknowledgement of the contributing institution. For research inquiries about specific objects, contact the University of Tennessee, Knoxville -- Libraries.

relatedItem.abstract: Tennessee’s history between the end of the American Civil War (1865) and the end of World War II (1945) often gets ignored. Citizenship—what that has meant and how that has changed—is at the heart of this digital exploration into Tennessee history and culture “between the wars." The stories you can explore through the objects, songs, photographs, paintings, and documents of this website are often those of challenges and obstacles placed before those who pursued the rights and benefits of citizenship.

mods.note: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
